National Association of Educational Broadcasters
1346 CONNECTICUT AVENUE WASHINGTON 36, D. C,
OFFICE OF RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
March 12, 1964
Mr. Edward A. Hodge, General Manager
Trade Department
Harcourt, Brace and World, Inc.
757 Third Avenue
New York 17, New York
Dear Mr. Hodge:
We are requesting authorization from the Harcourt, Brace and World
Publishing Company to use a poem by Carl Sandburg, "A.E.F.'*, for
which we understand you hold the copyright.
Permission to use this material is being sought by the N.A.E.B. in
connection with an arrangement we have with the Voice of America to
develop an English Through Poetry series. The 13 commentaries for these
programs are being written by Professor M. L. Rosenthal of New York
University. The Voice of America, in turn, working closely with Professor
Rosenthal, will produce 13 quarter-hour radio scripts on the basis of
these commentaries. The radio programs themselves are intended for broad¬
cast to listeners overseas, and are being designed to appeal to the
listeners interest in poetry in the English langauge.
In each script the poem will be read in its entirety, and the listeners
will also be invited to read the lines aloud in appropriate units after
the radio speaker.
Permission is sought both for the broadcast by the Xoice °£ America to
overseas countires and for broadcast in countries where local radio
stations may receive the taped programs through the United States Infor¬
mation Agency. Permission is also sought for publication of the poems
that might be published in any given country (with the aid or supervision
of U.S.I.A.,) and distributed free or at cost to radio listeners.
Permission is also sought for eventual publication of the materials in a
similar study booklet to be produced by U.S.I.A. for gratis distribution
to overseas listeners who request such booklets.
We hope we will hear from you shortly and that authorization to use these
materials in the manner which we have outlined will be forthcoming.
